doc.title: Magnum Fireside Chat Replay and our 10 key takeaways
doc.source_uri: 2025-08-28/Replay Corporate Access Magnum Fireside Chat Replay and our 10 key takeawaysReplay Corporate Access Magnum Fireside Chat_2025-08-28

passages.text: Replay: Corporate Access

If you missed the fireside chat, the replay can be accessed below. We also outline our 10 takeaways. What struck us is how much potential there is to deliver better growth at the same time as strong margin delivery. Magnum's moat is sizeable, but the trick will be to turn potential into reality asap
Please see below replay information for the event held on Wednesday, 27 August 2025 at 1:00pm - 2:15pm UTC
This replay is strictly and solely for the benefit of the intended recipients. Barclays Events Terms of Service and the Barclays Events Privacy Notice

This research report has been prepared in whole or in part by equity research analysts based outside the US who are not registered/qualified as research analysts with FINRA.
Please see analyst certifications and important disclosures beginning on page 7. Completed: 27- Aug- 25, 23:37 GMT Released: 28- Aug- 25, 05:00 GMT Restricted - External

One of the surprising things to us is the ice cream experience of the management team below the C Suite. A cadre of very experienced general managers have been installed in all the key country roles with many having more than a decade of experience. The reason CEO Peter ter Kolve highlighted for these people upgrades is that, it is very different running a relatively smaller division in a large company like Unilever vs a listed standalone pure play ice cream company. This big change of its operating model required a major talent intervention. There was also the need to have more senior people with public markets experience, which it now has with its CFO and head of HR. Although many are recent hires, quite a few have been through a few (ice cream) seasons, so they already have good experience about how best to squeeze growth, margins and cash.

Peter ter Kolve highlighted that in a recent internal survey which asked what Magnum employees thought about the momentum and the direction of travel of the company, the engagement scores of Magnum's senior directors (work level 3 just below the divisional heads), where a total of 155 responded, \(82\%\) (in June 25) said they would recommend working at Magnum to a friend up from \(58\%\) in Jan- 25. We think this kind of jump is meaningful and a good sign. Also in a related question as part of the same survey, \(60\%\) of all Magnum employees in June 25 expect the business performance of Magnum to improve over the next six months. Clearly some investors might take these stats with a grain of salt, but at face value, usually when the employees believe in the vision it is more likely to become a reality. Peter ter Kolve summed up the mindset and culture which he is trying to instill, which is that of an 68bn revenue start up.

It is easy to forget that Unilever or Magnum now has 160 years of experience in Ice Cream. Its Breyers brand was originally founded in 1866. This heritage matters as it has been the category creator in Ice Cream for a long time. Froneri has performed better than Unilever in recent years for sure, but portfolio for portfolio, we think Magnum's is materially better. It owns four of the five biggest brands in the category (Heart/Walls (revs €2.8bn), Magnum (revs €2bn), Ben&Jerry's (€1.1bn) and Cornetto (€0.8bn). Magnum also has double the freezer real estate (3m Freezers) of its nearest competitor and has a global market share which is \(21\%\) vs Froneri's \(9\%\) . Magnum's market share broken down by region is highest in Europe at \(31\%\) , followed by the US at \(19\%\) and \(11\%\) in ROW. The one big market where Magnum is not in a number one position is China where the market leader is Yili. However in China it is positioning itself as a disruptive (super) premium player.

The fact that Froneri has trebled its EBIT over five years whereas Magnum has been flat can be looked in one of two ways. The negative view is that it is simply evidence of the difficult and complex nature of ice cream, or alternatively the positive view is that the separation will allow Magnum to do exactly what Froneri has done for the last six years. Magnum's independence (from Unilever) means it will be able to curate a distinctive operating model and strategy outside of Unilever. We are minded to take the more positive view. Salespeople who have previously been selling multiple categories to retailers like Carrefour or Walmart will now be \(100\%\) focused on ice cream, and we can't see how this will not be a big unlock in terms of day to day execution. We certainly understand that in the short term it will mean that capex will need to go up and returns come down to unlock the full value opportunity.
There seems to be a bit of an investor perception that the barriers to entry in ice cream are on the low side and that the topic was discussed in detail during the conversation.

The point that came across is that making ice cream is technically difficult which includes everything from precisiondosing to multi- components and surface shaping. A good example of a technically difficult new innovation is Magnum Bon Bons. Miniaturization in ice cream is complex because it requires a major reformulation including more focus on slow melting properties which requires precise changes to fat, sugar and stabilization ratios. It also requires non standard production lines demanding flexible extrusion lines which requires significant investments.

The other key point is that it is easy to make ice cream at home but it is very difficult to scale globally. It requires significant investment in distribution and cold chain technology, and Magnum sees its 3m freezer real estate footprint as a significant competitive advantage.

Al and digitalization are also becoming increasingly important moats. One of Magnum's biggest opportunities is to not have out of stocks when there are heat waves, as this is the optimum moment where it can make outsized margins which are unpromoted and therefore is very profitable volume growth. The biggest challenge however is predicting weather patterns 2- 3 weeks in advance to make sure they have the right SKUs in the right places. Google weather forecasting data is making sizeable strides in accuracy and, as Magnum gets closer to calling the right weather patterns even down to individual zip codes, this could be a game changer in terms of optimizing its resource allocation.

We felt that CEO Peter ter Kulve was a little bit critical of Unilever's previous pricing strategies in Ice Cream which saw too little pricing in 2022, and then over compensated with too much pricing in 2023 which resulted in material volume erosion and share loss.

Being much smarter on pricing and revenue management sounds like it is now a top priority, so not as to repeat previous mis- steps. The pricing Magnum has taken in the last year has resulted in much lower volume elasticity than previously. For example, Magnum's pricing was \(6\%\) but they still delivered \(4\%\) volume growth, so overall the brand posted \(10\%\) organic growth in Q2- 25.

Another decisive point of difference with Unilever is that Magnum has doubled down in the US in the club and discount channel and the kids ice cream category which had been de- emphasised by Unilever. This has already paid quick dividends for Magnum which has regained leadership from Froneri in the US ice cream market, which is important, as the US is the world's largest ice cream market. The job now will be to cement this leadership position in the US and open up its market share gap vs Froneri.

CEO Peter ter Kulve said that Magnum's market share gains currently are very broad based. Its 12- week market share is tracking ahead of its 52- week share, which shows the business has good short- term momentum. Magnum's Q2 organic growth was \(7.1\%\) of which \(5\%\) was from volume. It has also recently regained overall market leadership (from Froneri) in the US. It seems to us that innovation has been stepping up with Magnum Bon Bons, Cornetto Max, and Yasso poppables performing well. We are also intrigued about the R&D and science behind the launch of its new glow in the dark Hydro:ICE brand.

One of the big things that is changing under the leadership of new CEO Peter ter Kulve is that Magnum will now grow its established installed freezer cabinets. This is crucial in growing volume and getting after the significant white space opportunities that it has. Magnum has 3 million installed freezers around the world which is double its nearest competitor but admitted this number has been surprisingly declining on average by around \(2\%\) per year. The reason for this is that Unilever was very focused on profit per freezer but Peter ter Kulve made the point that you can't cut your freezer numbers to victory. Given ice cream is all about availability, Magnum aspires to develop a Coca Cola mindset of having its ice cream brands always 'within thumbs reach of desire'.

The average payback on a freezer is 2- 3 years which is good, but he also said that you have to accept that whilst sometimes the payback can be much better than this average, say six months, sometimes you have to accept that in some circumstances the payback might be up to four years. Therefore the practice of reducing freezer numbers has already been reversed. What we would like to know at the CMD is what the cadence of freezer growth will look like in the next few years. Clearly as more of its freezers will use smart AI and monitoring tools, it should also be able to improve the payback on its less well performing freezer estate.

Magnum has a very good Ice Cream business in Turkey with market share around \(80\%\) , but has more work to do in other emerging markets. It has driven very significant per capita consumption in Turkey, now 6 litres per head per annum, and the plan now is to take the Turkish playbook to other big emerging markets such as China and India. Populous countries such as India, Pakistan and Bangladesh have per capita consumption of ice cream of only half a litre per capita, or twelve times less than Turkey. The opportunity to significantly improve both penetration and per capita consumption in these countries is huge with decades of runway.

When asked about whether Magnum's high ROW margins could come down as it invests and goes after the EM opportunity, Peter ter Kulve made the interesting point that it is not a given that traditional supermarkets in large emerging markets such as India will necessarily be the winning channels in ice creams. This is an important point as it is typically supermarkets and aggressive pricing strategies that usually push down margins. Growth of quick commerce in countries such as India is rapid and is dis- intermediating supermarkets, and in the growing e- commerce channel margins can be attractive, meaning that Magnum's high ROW margins can be sustained even as channels shift rapidly.

The other interesting point is that Asian consumers are very aspirational and their buying habits are heavily skewed by influencers. Gen Z consumers, especially in Asia, are reshaping the ice cream market with their demands for variety, innovation and authenticity. Magnum has a real opportunity to take ice cream out of the freezer into the fashion and lifestyle space with significantly more digital assets and content.

Magnum is increasingly working with influencers such as Magnum brand ambassador Charlie xx. This resonates with Asian consumers as well as other younger consumers around the world and importantly allows Magnum to dynamically optimize digital media and influencers to ultimately drive demand creation.

53% of Magnum sales fall between May and September and that has been the predictable pattern over 20 years. Magnum's channel mix is 60% in home, 40% out of home and obviously the retail/In home business is far less seasonal than out of home.

However, there is also a geographic hedge (Northern vs Southern hemisphere) as well as the fact that Magnum's e- commerce business is hardly seasonal at all. This is important because e- commerce is the fastest growing part of the market. This is an important consideration as investors will naturally think that Magnum will have a tough comp in 2026 because of this year's heatwave in Europe.

Under Unilever's ownership, Ice Cream manufacturing costs had been optimized and were the focus but its logistics and overhead costs remained way too high. Going forward, Magnum will have very lean HQ and regional structures so that it can better deliver real operating leverage as it drives volume growth.

Right now, it doesn't have an efficient route to market with ice cream travelling way too far which elevates costs. Ice cream produced in Italy would routinely be shipped to Sweden which makes little sense, and this will be changed over time as it looks to really localise its model, which will require some upfront costs but should yield long- term significant benefits. In time, it might require more plants and Peter ter Kule mentioned one more factory in the US might be necessary, but for now the priority is to improve its current factory capacity utilisation first.

On procurement costs there is also opportunity in how Magnum buys and how much vertical integration can be done. Magnum unlike Unilever plans to be more tactical on hedging and will look to take views, which might mean that it extends hedging covers beyond six months and uses derivative instruments such as collars to lock in favourable pricing.

Magnum has already announced medium- term gross productivity savings of €500m. We expect to hear more about the phasing and the retention drop through of these savings to margins at the CMD. We do however know there are three big savings buckets which are coming from supply chain transformation, overhead reductions and tech enabled productivity. Management has also previously said that it is looking to cap overheads in absolute terms at around €900m.

The rise of GLP- 1 medications (e.g., Ozempic, Wegovy), used for weight loss and diabetes management, potentially poses a risk to ice cream consumption. A Cornell and Numerator joint research paper found that households with GLP- 1 patients reduced grocery spend by 6% with a 9% drop in ice cream buy rates vs a 3.9% increase in non users.

Peter ter Kule said that GLP is an important issue (especially with regards to the share prices of food companies) and for now he said it remains mostly a US issue. He said that for an 11% penetration of GLP- 1 drugs, US ice cream volume declines by a modest 0.5%. They had studied many sources to come to that conclusion. We have said in previous research we think it would be beneficial to go deeper into the GLP- 1 topic (and we still do) and share these sources so that investors can understand the rigour and methodology behind their calculations. This has been one consistent piece of feedback we have had from investors and actually tackling the GLP- 1 issue head on with more granularity would be beneficial in our view.

The other interesting point is that some consumers are increasingly seeing ice cream as a calorie efficient indulgence with the calorie count across different ice cream SKUs between 100 and 400 calories (per 100g) which is actually lower than traditional snacking SKUs such as chocolate or cookies more in the 400- 600 calorie range. The calorie count in water based ice lollies can be much lower at 50 calories or less. In terms of innovation, Peter ter Kulse said there has been a lot of work done on indulgence and health trends in ice cream but less innovation around refreshment and the ability for ice creams to do a better job in the hydration space, which could be a significant focus area for the company going forward. There is also plenty of work going on in R&D to reduce sugar levels which is technically difficult, but his view is that if their is the will and desire to do so, there is a way to reimagine the calorie count in ice- cream.

In our view, there will always be a place for more indulgent ice creams, especially if it is framed as an occasional treat. Going forward, if consumers eat less but more premium, this could actually play to the benefit of indulgent brands such as Magnum or Ben and Jerry's. A Kantar's GLP- 1 study (link) showed that \(75\%\) of GLP- 1 consumers say treats are still important sometimes, which is a positive for the ice- cream category.

Magnum will provide its financial algo on 9th September ahead of the spin in mid Nov. The prospectus is due to be published a week or so before the spin, which is a bit later than is ideal (from a modelling perspective) but we understand the work involved.

We expect Magnum to say at the CMD that the global ice cream market grows around \(3\% +\) and that it can beat the market (as it has been doing for the last 18 months). It has already been disclosed that Unilever will retain a \(20\%\) stake and the target leverage on spin will be 2.4x ND/EBITDA (starting EBITDA is c€1.3bn). We also know the plan is to step up A&P from \(>12\%\) to \(13\%\) with capex increasing from \(4\%\) to \(5\%\) . The CEO acknowledged that its current ROIC of \(23\%\) will come down as spend increases. We think it could say at the CMD that steady state ROIC is high teens. The main point for us on the CMD will be how Magnum calibrates the topline guidance, the retention rate of savings and whether it goes with a percentage margin target, an absolute EBIT target or more prudently margin growth above sales.

We would prefer Magnum to slightly err on the side of caution at the CMD and ensure it plays the expectations management game. Too many companies come out all guns blazing and live to regret it. Clearly giving enough of a carrot to investors to show what the true potential is, but leaving some of the firepower in the locker would be key. Admittedly this is a fine balancing act. Meeting and beating in its first year will be crucial in building credibility with investors and boosting its rating. Its share price will inevitably be choppy around the spin and the volatility could last for a while, but should settle down quickly if it can start beating out of the gate.
Magnum CEO Fireside Chat: Initial Thoughts, 27 August 2025

Underweight - The stock is expected to underperform the unweighted expected total return of the industry coverage universe over a 12- month investment horizon.
Positive - industry coverage universe fundamentals/valuations are improving.
Neutral - industry coverage universe fundamentals/valuations are steady, neither improving nor deteriorating.

Historical stock prices and price targets may have been adjusted for stock splits and dividends.

Valuation Methodology: Our price target is driven by a relative P/E methodology; given Unilever has both Food and HPC exposure, we compare it with a Food & HPC blended multiple. We value Unilever in- line to EU Food & HPC 2 year average blended forward PE of c.20x. This implies that Unilever reverts to trading in line with its 10- year average fwd P/E, which we believe is warranted in light of the following: 1) the new organisational structure, which we believe should help unlock significant value, 2) the company's exposure to India, which, at 11%, is the highest among European stocks along with a high weightage to EMS, 3) bold management changes done in a short time period, 4) synergies from a shift to a regional focus for the portfolio., 5) higher focus on premiumization, US, India & beauty

Risks which May Impede the Achievement of the Barclays Research Valuation and Price Target: 1) Losses in out- of- home Foods & Refreshments exceed in- home consumption benefits in Foods and stronger Home/Hygiene growth post Covid- 19, leading to significantly lower top- line growth than we expect; 2) the company's key market of India (11% of sales) doesn't perform as expected; 3) A sharp slowdown in the company's key LatAm markets (Brazil, Mexico, Argentina, Chile) hurts its growth prospects; and 4) competitor market share gains accelerate, further pressuring Unilever's already weak top- line growth.

**Valuation Methodology:** Our price target is driven by a relative P/E methodology; given Unilever has both Food and HPC exposure, we compare it with a Food & HPC blended multiple. We value Unilever in-line to EU Food & HPC 2 year average blended forward PE of c.20x. This implies that Unilever reverts to trading in line with its 10-year average fwd P/E, which we believe is warranted in light of the following: 1) the new organisational structure, which we believe should help unlock significant value, 2) the company's exposure to India, which, at 11%, is the highest among European stocks along with a high weightage to EMS, 3) bold management changes done in a short time period, 4) synergies from a shift to a regional focus for the portfolio., 5) higher focus on premiumization, US, India & beauty

**Risks which May Impede the Achievement of the Barclays Research Valuation and Price Target:** 1) Losses in out-of-home Foods & Refreshments exceed in-home consumption benefits in Foods and stronger Home/Hygiene growth post Covid-19, leading to significantly lower top-line growth than we expect; 2) the company's key market of India (11% of sales) doesn't perform as expected; 3) A sharp slowdown in the company's key LatAm markets (Brazil, Mexico, Argentina, Chile) hurts its growth prospects; and 4) competitor market share gains accelerate, further pressuring Unilever's already weak top-line growth.

Sustainable Investing Related Research: There is currently no globally accepted framework or definition (legal, regulatory or otherwise) of, nor market consensus as to what constitutes a 'sustainable', 'ESG', 'green', 'climate- friendly' or an equivalent company, investment, strategy or consideration or what precise attributes are required to be eligible to be categorised by such terms. This means there are different ways to evaluate a

company or an investment and so different values may be placed on certain sustainability credentials as well as adverse ESG- related impacts of companies and ESG controversies. The evolving nature of sustainable investing considerations, models and methodologies means it can be challenging to definitively and universally classify a company or investment under a sustainable investing label and there may be areas where such companies and investments could improve or where adverse ESG- related impacts or ESG controversies exist. The evolving nature of sustainable finance related regulations and the development of jurisdiction- specific regulatory criteria also means that there is likely to be a degree of divergence as to the interpretation of such terms in the market. We expect industry guidance, market practice, and regulations in this field to continue to evolve.

Any information, data, image, or other content including from a third party source contained, referred to herein or used for whatsoever purpose by Barclays or a third party ("Information"), in relation to any actual or potential 'ESG', 'sustainable' or equivalent objective, issue, factor or consideration is not intended to be relied upon for ESG or sustainability classification, regulatory regime or industry initiative purposes ("ESG Regimes"), unless otherwise stated. Nothing in these materials, including any images included therein, is intended to convey, suggest or indicate that Barclays considers or represents any product, service, person or body mentioned in these materials as meeting or qualifying for any ESG or sustainability classification, label or similar standards that may exist under ESG Regimes. Barclays has not conducted any assessment of compliance with ESG Regimes. Parties are reminded to make their own assessments for these purposes.

IRS Circular 230 Prepared Materials Disclaimer: Barclays does not provide tax advice and nothing contained herein should be construed to be tax advice. Please be advised that any discussion of U.S. tax matters contained herein (including any attachments) (i) is not intended or written to be used, and cannot be used, by you for the purpose of avoiding U.S. tax- related penalties; and (ii) was written to support the promotion or marketing of the transactions or other matters addressed herein. Accordingly, you should seek advice based on your particular circumstances from an independent tax advisor.
